data.title: “I have been rich, and I have been poor. Believe me baby, rich is better!”
data.meta_description: This began a steady pattern of moving from home to home for Ella: first she lived with her stepfather for about a year, then her aunt. At this age she started working as a lookout for a bordello and…
data.text:
Have you ever wondered what she actually meant by that? What was her personal life experience?

Here’s a brief look at Ella Fitzgerald’s life in key transitions from poor to rich:

She had a tumultuous young life, but by the third grade was demonstrating a unique talent by dancing and singing at school, on the way to school with friends, and at church.

Her mother suddenly died when she was 15, in a car accident.

This began a steady pattern of moving from home to home for Ella: first she lived with her stepfather for about a year, then her aunt. At this age she started working as a lookout for a bordello and with Mafia affiliated gambling rings in the Bronx. This led to placement into the Colored Orphan Asylum, and because of overcrowding, she was later moved to the New York Training School for Girls — a reformatory school.

At the age of 17 she went on stage at the Apollo theater during Amateur Nights.
